unnormalised: ## Return Policies: Because Even Godrej Almirahs Aren't Always Perfect
normalised: ## Return Policies: Because Even Godrej Almirahs Aren't Always Perfect

unnormalised: Let's be honest, folks. Shopping, especially online, is a bit like gambling. You see that gorgeous Banarasi silk saree, the one that promises to transform you into a Bollywood diva, and you think, "Jackpot!" Then it arrives, and you realize it makes you look more like a slightly crumpled potato sack. That, my friends, is where the humble return policy comes in.

unnormalised: Think of return policies as your escape hatch from retail purgatory. They are the Lakshmi of the e-commerce world, offering a chance to recoup your investment when that "must-have" gadget turns out to be a "must-return" headache.
normalised: Think of return policies as your escape hatch from retail purgatory. They are the Lakshmi of the e-commerce world, offering a chance to recoup your investment when that "must-have" gadget turns out to be a "must-return" headache.

unnormalised: Now, navigating return policies can be trickier than figuring out the IPL playoffs. Some are as straightforward as asking for seconds at a Diwali feast. Others are as convoluted as a plotline from a Ekta Kapoor serial. You might find yourself jumping through hoops the size of Mumbai's potholes, providing photographic evidence, filling out forms that require a PhD in bureaucratic jargon, and explaining why the slightly faded colour on your new kurta is unacceptable (even though your chacha said it looked "quite nice").

unnormalised: Remember that time I bought a "slightly used" treadmill from "Sharma's Fitness Emporium" online? The return policy was longer than the Ganga. Turns out, "slightly used" meant it had apparently been used to train an entire marathon team… in the Sahara Desert. Getting a refund was like pulling teeth from a stubborn donkey. They wanted pictures, Dr.'s notes, and a sworn affidavit that I hadn't intentionally sabotaged the thing.

unnormalised: Moral of the story? Read the fine print! Before you click "buy" on that 800 sq ft carpet or that supposedly "genuine" leather wallet for Rs. 500, understand the return policy. Know your rights, people! Don't let them treat you like a roadside chai wallah. You deserve better. You deserve a smooth return process, even if your sartorial choices deserve a stern talking-to. And if all else fails, remember: a good lawyer is cheaper than therapy. (Just kidding… mostly.)
